_meta.title: Trello - Course (Roadmap)
_meta.description: Strategic roadmap for Trello circa 2011. Complements the Destination example. Plausible founding story optimized for teaching, not historical accuracy.

strategic.visionReference: Work should be visible. When you can see everything laid out in front of you - what's done, what's happening, what's next - collaboration stops feeling like coordination overhead and starts feeling like flow. We believe the simple act of moving a card from 'Doing' to 'Done' should feel satisfying, that teams deserve tools that fade into the background and let the work shine through. We're building the whiteboard that travels with you, the sticky note that never falls off, the shared brain for any team doing anything.
strategic._visionNote: Vision is owned by Destination (Canvas). This is a reference copy displayed for team context. Single source of truth = trello-destination.json

diagnosis.statement: Project management tools have failed small teams not because of missing features, but because of forced complexity. Teams abandon Basecamp, Jira, and MS Project not because these tools can't do what they need, but because the cognitive overhead of using them exceeds the value of tracking the work. The 30-second learning curve is not a nice-to-have - it's the entire problem we're solving.
assumptions: Current tools assume teams want comprehensive project management when most just want visible work tracking
Existing freemium products (Dropbox, Evernote) prove users will start free and convert to paid if genuinely useful
The browser is now capable enough for drag-and-drop that feels native

real: Browser performance limits (can't match native app speed)
Fog Creek funding timeline (~18 months to revenue)

guidingPrinciples: When choosing between features and simplicity, we choose simplicity - every new capability must not increase cognitive load for first-time users
We'll know we're successful when people teach Trello to colleagues in under 60 seconds without documentation
Our approach to product decisions: if it requires explaining in the UI, we haven't designed it simply enough
Word-of-mouth growth over paid acquisition - the product experience is our marketing
focusAreas: Core board/list/card interaction - make drag-and-drop feel effortless and immediate
Real-time collaboration - multiple people on the same board must feel like magic
Zero-friction onboarding - from landing page to productive use in under 2 minutes
Freemium conversion discovery - understand what power users actually need and will pay for
tradeoffs: We will not build Gantt charts, time tracking, or resource management - that's enterprise PM territory we're avoiding
We will not add workflow automation or complex rules - teams should adapt Trello to their process, not configure Trello
We will defer mobile apps until web product is proven - focus beats breadth in year one
We will not pursue enterprise sales - small teams are our beachhead, enterprise comes later

goals.name: User Activation
goals.description: Increase in users who create their first board and add at least 3 cards within 24 hours of signup, indicating they understand the product and find immediate value
goals.strategicConnection: Validates our zero-friction onboarding focus area - if users don't activate immediately, our simplicity thesis fails

goals.name: Team Collaboration
goals.description: Increase in boards with 2+ active collaborators (multiple people making changes in a 7-day period), indicating Trello is being used for real team coordination
goals.strategicConnection: Tests real-time collaboration focus area - Trello only wins if teams collaborate on boards, not individuals working alone

goals.name: 90-Day Retention
goals.description: Increase in teams still actively using Trello 90 days after first board creation, indicating the product has lasting value beyond initial curiosity
goals.strategicConnection: Ultimate test of our simplicity discipline - complex tools get abandoned, simple tools become habit

activation.name: Launch public beta with Joel on Software announcement
activation.description: Release Trello to Joel Spolsky's audience with invitation system to control initial load

activation.name: Onboarding template boards (3 examples)
activation.description: Pre-built template boards for common use cases: product roadmap, marketing calendar, personal todo

collaboration.name: Real-time cursor indicators
collaboration.description: Show who else is viewing the board with live cursor positions for co-presence awareness

activation.name: Improve first-board experience
activation.description: Users can create useful boards faster by better default list names and inline suggestions
activation.problemSolved: New users stare at blank board wondering what to put in lists - analysis shows 30% bounce at this step

collaboration.name: Enable frictionless board sharing
collaboration.description: Team members can invite others to boards via email/link without recipient needing to sign up first
collaboration.problemSolved: Collaboration requires all members to create accounts upfront - creates friction when someone just wants to share work

collaboration.name: Activity feed on boards
collaboration.description: Board members see recent changes/comments/additions in a timeline showing what happened since they last looked
collaboration.problemSolved: When returning to an active board, users can't quickly see what changed - forces them to scan entire board

retention.name: Email digests for inactive users
retention.description: Users who haven't visited in 7 days receive digest of activity on their boards to pull them back
retention.problemSolved: Teams forget about Trello after initial setup - need to build habit of checking boards regularly

activation.name: Investigate signup friction points
activation.description: Identify where users drop off between landing page and first useful board creation
researchQuestions: What percentage reach signup form vs. leave from landing page?
How many start signup but don't complete it?
How many complete signup but never create a board?
How many create empty board but never add cards?
learningGoals: Quantify conversion funnel from landing â†’ active user
Identify biggest drop-off point to prioritize improvements

collaboration.name: Understand premium collaboration features
collaboration.description: Explore what advanced collaboration needs exist that free users would pay to solve
researchQuestions: What limitations do power teams hit with free Trello?
Which teams outgrow Trello vs. which teams scale with it?
What collaboration features do Basecamp/Asana have that users miss?
Would teams pay for better search, larger attachments, admin controls?
learningGoals: Define freemium line - what stays free vs. what becomes paid
Validate premium tier pricing and feature set

retention.name: Study abandonment patterns
retention.description: Understand why teams stop using Trello after initial adoption
researchQuestions: What triggers a team to abandon an active board?
Do teams switch to competitors or abandon category entirely?
Is abandonment due to missing features or workflow mismatch?
Do teams abandon Trello or just specific boards?
learningGoals: Identify if retention is product issue or natural use case expiration
Determine if we can predict at-risk teams and intervene
